video.title: AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner Training 2020 - Full Course
video.description:
This course will help you become an AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner. You will get a complete understanding of the AWS Cloud platform and be prepared to take the certification exam. 

This knowledge and certification will open up job opportunities. You will be able to prove your expertise in AWS and cloud computing.

The exam can be taken anywhere as an online proctored exam.

🎥 Course developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro. Check out the ExamPro YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2EsmbKnDNE7y1N3nZYCuGw
🔗 ExamPro AWS Obsessed Certification Training: https://www.exampro.co
🔗 LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/exam...
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/examproco
📷 Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/exampro.co/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

☁️ Introduction
⌨️ (0:00:00) Meet Your Instructor Andrew Brown

☁️ Cloud Concepts

topLevelComment.author: Hugo Ludwig
topLevelComment.text:
Beware of AWS free offers; even after cancelling all services that generate charges, they make irregular charges, the resolution of disputes takes a long time. Personally I would not put my clients in the hands of AWS. Even when they admit you were charged without any reason, they take a lot of time to refund your money. After 4 months I´m still waiting a refund. Anyway they will still mistakenly charging you, every month. My solution was to block my Debit Card, and sue my bank for not protecting me against this forementioned mistakes. My bank charges me for a insurance every month.

I wonder If this is the way Jeff Bezos makes money to travel to the extratosphere.

topLevelComment.author: CamSlam8
topLevelComment.text: Around 20 minutes ago I passed my AWS Cloud Practitioner Certification! I spent probably less than 24 hours total studying for the exam the night before using pretty much only this course and 6 practice tests on udemy. I certainly do not recommend cramming like I did, and additionally I have around an year of IT experience through college, and studying for two other IT certifications, but it is certainly possible to complete it on a time crunch. I think this will be a very good certification to have, and wish good luck to all of you!

topLevelComment.author: Harrish Murugesan
topLevelComment.text:
I passed the Cloud Practitioner exam yesterday. I started going through this video in the morning and took the test at night and got a score of 792/1000. Honestly this has almost everything you need even in 2022. There are obviously a few more additions that are not covered here like AWS Ground Station, AWS Managed Services, etc but those are kinda intuitive in its name. Thank you so much to Andrew Brown for making this available for FREE! Absolute legend! 

P.S Yes, i have used AWS Beanstalk,Auto Scaling groups, security groups, Load Balancers, etc for building out a Web Application for a College Project so i am not an absolute beginner to AWS. But this video has 90% of the things necessary to pass the exam in 2022

topLevelComment.author: A Yu
topLevelComment.text: To everyone asking if this video is still relevant in 2022 and whether this video is better than the longer one - the answer to both is no. I took the exam today and I would not be surprised if I failed despite working in this field. Exams no longer show you a pass/fail score at the end, you have to wait up to five days to get your score via Email. I only studied using this video course. There are so many new technologies that have came out in the last two+ years that this video does not cover. The AWS exam does not tell you which technologies have been deprecated and replaced with what. There are also a number of questions on the exam that are much more specific than what is listed in this video. If you only use this video to study, you will probably not do well unless you are already working in the field. I would highly recommend looking at the longest 13 hour course as it is more recent and much more in depth than what this video covers. I flagged more than one third of my questions because I was not familiar with so many of the technologies and now I am anxiously waiting for my test results to be Emailed to me.

topLevelComment.author: A Yu
topLevelComment.text: For all of the people asking if this video is enough. Here's an honest opinion - I just took the exam today. It was much harder than I thought it would be and I was thrown off by all the new technologies that are not mentioned because this video is from 2019. I flagged over a third of the questions for review during the end of my review. I watched this video three times and wrote down notes from every topic. This video was not enough after seeing what the questions are. The exam also does not give you a pass or fail at the end anymore. I would not be surprised if I failed having only watched this video.

replies.author: Jane
replies.text:
Hi! The short answer to this is: this video is still very helpful but shouldn’t be your only source of information and you’d best use the exam guide as a red thread. Longer answer below.  

I took the exam recently and this video is very thorough and informative. The “cheat sheets” and graphics (of for example the support plans) are very helpful too, as is the final section where similar-ish sections get compared. If you watch this video and thoroughly study the AWS Cloud Practitioner Essentials module on AWS Skillbuilder, you’ve already covered a lot. 

Having said that — it’s best to check out the most recent exam guide on the AWS website too and carefully read through the possible topics mentioned as not all of those topics are covered by this video and the training module. I made the mistake of kind of slacking on that and encountered some material in the exam that was in a “blind spot” for me. I did pass, though; mostly focusing on the training module and using this video (and my hands-on job experience so far) as supplementary information ;) 

I believe this channel uploaded a more recent video on this exam, but that one is 13 hours, so I personally didn’t bother with that one. 

Best of luck!

topLevelComment.author: Tony Winner
topLevelComment.text: I started studying on Christmas Day (12/25/21) and took my test on Jan. 7 2022 and passed. Thank you. For those who would like to know, I used only this video, along with practice tests on his site along with an app on my iPhone to take practice exams. Many of the practice exams had a few questions that weren’t covered in this exam but I just chose to learn them anyway and wrote them down. I firmly believe after taking enough practice exams you get a great feel of what the test will be like, how things are worded, and what to expect. You’ll be in great shape with this video to take it. When taking the practice exams, I only did fairly well, and sometimes even failed others. But I believe it prepared me for how to take the real test. So don’t let practice exams be too much of a determining factor for if you think you are ready. Just let it be a guide. Good luck to all!

replies.author: Adam Fiergang
replies.text: @rochel hirsch One thing I would recommend is not relying on the video for everything. If you don't understand Lambda functions for example, you can google what a Lambda function is. An AWS Lambda isn't different from any other Lambda function. I'm lucky enough to have a background in tech, so a lot of the terms weren't new for me, but if they were I might pause the video and learn what those terms are before continuing. Also, even though you can't use your notes on the exam, that doesn't mean taking them is a bad idea. It's very helpful for learning.

topLevelComment.author: metaprog46and2
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed my exam 7/22. First try. Took about 40 mins. No prior AWS experience. Actual score arrives in 3-5 days, but I'd ballpark, fairly confidently, that I answered circa 80-90% of the Q's correctly.  I mention this to provide context to some of the following thoughts:
1.) This video is def helpful. Most of the material is still relevant. But it's not exhaustive. Plenty new AWS services not covered in this video. Unless one has an IT background, it's hard for me to see folks passing based solely on this particular study resource (maybe just sliding by). I took practice exams & read study material from a couple other sources.  2-3 questions were exact copies from sample exams, another 2-3 slight variations.  Extremely helpful.  If you want to ensure you pass on the first shot, and want to do so confidently, seek out other resources in addition to this vid.

2.) I studied appx. 3-4 hours a day for 4 consecutive days.  Another 1-hr review on Day 5, just before the test.  That's 13-17 hrs total.  My background - Data Scientist, grad degree, more quant & tech-adjacent than IT. Folks of similar background (i.e. non-IT quant/analytical/dev) I'd ballpark would need somewhere around 15-30 hours total to have a good probability of passing. Non-IT/non-quant/non-dev...definitely more.

3.). Read the Q's carefully. Often 2 choices seem equally accurate upon a cursory read. So don't just gloss over the wording...read it carefully. The phrasing & specific choice of diction can mean the difference b/w a right & wrong answer. 

Hope folks find this helpful.

Some suggestions / constructive criticism here:

1. Less focus on Billing/Pricing if the goal of the video is to prepare for the exam. It's just a small fraction of the exam contents and you spent 1/4 of the video on it. 

2. Watch your speech, you tend to end sentences with a rhetorical "ok?" question quite a lot. Far from  ruining the course, but it does get distracting after a while (it's a 4h video).

Good job, anyway!

topLevelComment.author: ILovRainy
topLevelComment.text:
Just finished the CCP exam at home, a few things to demonstrate...
1. I have taken the exam with PSI, the proctor was given strict orders to check ur IDs and your desk, basically everything. He made me removing EVERYTHING on the desk except for ur computer. So think again before u choose to take it at home.

2. In my opinion, the exam is harder than I thought, I used this video, AWS essential training and sample questions on udemy. I reviewed over and over again, but the exam is still very challenging to me. But doing sample questions and reviewing did help, otherwise I am pretty sure I will get a much lower score...

3. The result will not come out right a way(**maybe I was wrong, based on aws website, it will tell u if u pass right a way)  official result will take up to 5 business days... 5 mins before the exam is due. PSI will prompt if u need extra time or quit since it has been 90 mins(sth like that), I think it was weird since I had 5 mins left but I had finished it already. When u click quit, the whole PSI browser will be closed. I have heard that some people who finished the exam early and left, the submission of their exam got disapproved since they left without letting the proctor knew, either PSI or Pearson I am not sure....

I hope I can pass thou! Gd luck for any other people who is gonna take AWS CCP.

topLevelComment.author: sami
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed the exam: this is wat I did hopefully it helps:
1. Day1: Watched the video @ 2X and took notes. Booked exam for day 3
2. Day2: Did same sample questions from: https://www.examtopics.com/exams/amazon/aws-certified-cloud-practitioner/view/ (over 633 free sample questions: did only 120)
3. Day3: Exam day. Watched the video at 4X (used this "Video Speed Controller" to help watch videos at faster speed). Then Went to 'above site and did 80 questions.

NOTE: The extension Video Speed Controller is free and I have been using it for a while now and am used to watching videos at 2X (it goes upto 16X but max I use is 5X).
Another exam resource: https://www.itexams.com/exam/AWS%20Certified%20Cloud%20Practitioner (also free but did not use this as 200 qstns where more than enough for me).
GOOD LUCK AND HOPE THIS HELPS.

topLevelComment.author: Jonesy's Cycle Vlogs
topLevelComment.text:
Passed on my first attempt a few weeks ago. 

Wondering whether this will help you pass?  Ignore all the Braggy comments from people on here bigging themselves up, they create the idea that you only need to revise for a few days and you will pass, when really they are just trying to show how clever they are. 

This video definitely helps, but if you use this as your only resource you will likely fail.

Take as many free practice tests you can find online, make sure you play around on your own AWS account.  You’re looking at at least 20 hours of revision if you have no hands on experience with AWS.

I managed to find a sale on at Udemy for the cloud practitioner course for £12.  That was the resource that helped more than anything. My advice is, don’t take short cuts and try to do everything just through YouTube videos, it’s definitely worth investing a little in training resources.

topLevelComment.author: David Jaramillo
topLevelComment.text:
JUST TOOK THE TEST. 3/11/21. 

Okay so the test has questions on:

Best Cloud Practices. 
If you were to run a relational database, what would you run it on.

What does AWS handle for you? Know responsible model into detail 

Does AWS automate pentesting was mentioned 

What services have file storage?

Know instance pricing examples and use cases. 

Asked if aws patches underlying Operating system 

Asked very detailed questions about cloud watch / org / billing .

Asked some trusted adviser questions 

Asked a few instance pricing questions 

Use tutorial dojo practice exams. They had sooo many of the same type of questions

This AWS practice quiz consists of 65 questions with a mix of questions on core AWS services, including all services which are at the AWS CCP level. At the end of the test, you get to review your answers and find detailed explanations of why each answer is wrong or right along with reference links for each question. We strongly believe in the value of practice exams that prepare you thoroughly for the real exam so that you get to pass the first time with a great score. Please don’t feel discouraged if you score lower than expected in this sample exam. We have got you covered with our comprehensive AWS Training Resources that will ensure your exam success.
Assess your exam readiness with 6 sets of full-length practice tests (65 questions each) that reflect the difficulty of the Amazon Web Services exam questions and are the most similar to the real AWS exam experience available. Our exam simulator includes more than 390 unique practice questions that are timed and scored and the closest to the real AWS exam. With these popular Practice Tests, you’ll know when you are ready to pass your AWS Cloud Practitioner exam!
The test is according to the updated syllabus of AWS.

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Holcombe
topLevelComment.text: I have just taken my exam this morning, and passed the AWS Practitioner Cert on the first try.  My primary study material (over four days of studying) was taking the AWS Practitioner 6 hour course, and repeatedly taking the final exam in that course (I think I took it 6-7 times in 4 days).  That final exam mimics the actual exam I took very well.  I did watch your course above last night which was helpful, but got into the "weeds" at times.  I would say that your examples of logging in and manipulating an AWS account is great for users to manipulate our own accounts, but the manipulation of the account is not part of the exam I took.   My exam was all about knowing the names of the services offered, what they do and knowing the AWS verbiage (which you do cover in your course).  I will use this course as a reference, as I work within my own account.  "The how to instructions are excellent" Thank you!

topLevelComment.author: indischedeutscher
topLevelComment.text:
I am a non-IT automotive professional who has been working in cloud sales for the past 1 year. Words like "instance", "aaS" , "Database", and "Networks" were Greek and Latin to my ears. I still do not have any hands on experience in AWS. My preparation was as follows:
- Close to 60% of my learning happened through this video and by making detailed notes.
- Brief reading of the 5 pillars of the AWS architected framework and best practices.
- Subsequently, I practiced 6 Udemy exams, which touch on some extra AWS services and also covers some concepts such as Shared Responsibility Model in greater detail. 
Thanks a lot Andrew Brown for this fanstastic free material, which helped me pass the exam with 905/1000 points in the first try.

topLevelComment.author: Soumyakant Tripathy
topLevelComment.text:
Andrew - You are doing a ton of service by providing free AWS content. THANK YOU!!! I cleared the exam in my first try with absolutely no background of cloud whatsoever by studying about 2 hours everyday for 6 days and giving 3 practice exams on the 7th day while also taking the exam the same day. My study plan was as follows
1. I went through your video twice and all hands on once to understand the AWS console (strongly recommend to do the "follow alongs").
2. Went through the AWS cloud practitioner essentials (2nd edition) videos once (It's free and is present in the AWS portal).
3. Gave 3 practice exams before sitting for the main exam.
In my opinion this much should be enough to clear, however consistency is the key. I would suggest everyone to study everyday for at least 1-2 hours in order to not lose momentum. Hope this helps.

FYI... the exam simulator will explain in detail the multiple choice selections. Hope this helps.

topLevelComment.author: BrosWithSwag
topLevelComment.text:
Passed the AWS CCP exam yesterday. 
Did 1 day of studying (Full day Sunday):
Watched this video, try to relate concepts to something familiar with (I chose game industry, and how each service could be used in the industry).
Took 2 FREE practice exams (If you sign up a new account on linuxacademy, u get 35 gems/rubies. each practice is 13 gems).
Reviewed each question with the links they put in the questions if you miss it (AWS links).
Skim whitepapers (4 listed on AWS website)
Get a good night sleep.

Monday (Day of the exam):
Rewatched from 2:45:00 to end TWICE, really drilling those services with the game industry (as mentioned above).
Reviewed Shared Responsibility Model and pricing models.
Yolo take test.
Pass
???
Profit (well technically neg, since exam costs $100, but i get an online certificate)

Prior experience: Undergrad is Business Finance (pretty money oriented major, so pricing stuff easy to grasp)
Grad school is Comp sci
0 AWS experience or exposure in workplace/school (heard it exists, that's about it)

topLevelComment.text:
Good content and the follow along sections give you a good understanding of the services. And his slides are very good also. In my opinion, this is a good base but will not be enough to pass unless you get lucky with the questions . I got practice exams from Udemy ($15 for 6 practice exams) and I wouldn't have passed without them. They give very good notes on the answers for all questions, correct and incorrect.The test is tricky, read the questions(and answers) very carefully. I studied for about a week. Leave about 15-20 mins for setting up secure browser etc if you are taking it online.

Thanks
Good2KnowVideos

topLevelComment.author: Jim Lee
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed the ccp exam. The score was 938. I spent about 2 weeks. I have very limited knowledge of AWS. The only thing I am doing at work is to run the cloudFormation templates devops prepared for us. Here is the studying plan I used to prepare for this exam. Hope it could help other people who intend to pass the exam.
1. Watch the official AWS CCP training video.
2. Watch this video.
3. Do the test bank on udemy (AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner: 6 Full Practice Exams 2020).  I got below 80% in each test set.
4. Do the test bank again. I got above 80% but below 90% in each test set
5. Watch this video one more time.
6. Do the test bank the third time   90% above in each test set.
7. Have some notes from this video and test bank explanations. Read and memorize all the notes prior to exam day.
P.S. I don't think I had seen any questions in the real exam existed in the udemy test bank. This test bank just helps you with aws knowledge enforcement.

topLevelComment.author: moonshiry
topLevelComment.text:
Passed my exam! Spent 3 days studying for it and took the exam on a saturday morning. got 82%! Just wanted to add my two cents here, this cert while considered basic can be difficult depending on your current knowledge background. I studied and am currently in IT so many of the concepts I am familiar. However, if you are from business or something non-IT, I would recommend that you take a month to study for this. Many concepts mentioned are high level and may fly over your heads because you weren't paying attention or just don't understand it enough to deduce the correct answer. E.g. the difference between different kinds of databases. For developers, once you learn the difference, its pretty hard to forget. You will instinctively choose the right one. But that may not be the case for a non-techie. So difficulty will vary but dont be discouraged!

For more general tips, after watching and reviewing this video, please go ahead and search for exam dumps/ questions online they will really help clarify your misunderstandings. A lot of questions in my exam focused on CloudTrail, Responsibilies of a cloud provider / customer *** vey impt. You really need to know each of the Amazon Technology listed. E.g. CloudTrail, CloudWatch, Amazon Macie, Route53. I would recommend pausing the video when you reach a new technology, go to the Amazon page, read up the description, then return back to this video to verify and reinforce your understanding. 

You need to know what metrics are available in budgets vs TCO, SNS, MFA and IAM, Pricing models, consolidated billing ( i had 4 questions on this), trusted advisor.

A few technologies were mentioned that weren't covered in the video and I'm not sure if it was the correct answer or not;
Amazon Fireeye
Amazon Cognito (3 questions mentioned this)

Overall, this video definitely helped + Harsh Baxi's Time Stamps for the topics + examtopics AWS certified cloud practitioner (This is the "forum" exam dump that helped me immensely)
I think i would have failed without the questions from examtopics.

Hope this helps! good luck everyone!

replies.author: moonshiry
replies.text:
​@I CHENG LIN Well I'm still figuring out the career path myself, which is why I'm pursuing this cert too so I'm no expert. If you have no experience in IT, it will be very difficult to get a job immediately as a solutions architect unless its some fresh graduate program where they are willing to train up hires with no background. The reason is because the cloud is a very large encompassing area of different topics. Networking, security, sysadmin, development. If you don't have experience, it's hard to pick up on the job because people will be coming to you with their problems and their current setups and you as the architect will have to try and create a map that will help them navigate their transition to the cloud.

What you can do, is look at it long term and do a tier list. 
Tier 1:
Learning goal: get a couple of IT certs. AWS is a big jump, but look more at basic certs that will solidify your fundamentals like Comptia Network+, Security+, Cisco CCNA. Because those are also common interview questions. The certs show that you understand the knowledge, and also put your position across to the recruiter that you are serious about moving into IT.

Career Goal: You can try applying for cloud associate jobs, but it will probably be tough. Expand your search criteria and first try to get a job in IT. Thats 50% of the battle won. Associate sysadmin roles, network admins, security analysts. Moving from 1 of these roles to the next cloud job will be much easier because you will have the knowledge + its a simple transition for recruiters looking to hire. The best advice  that I can give and I wish I knew about before I started working would be to look for large MNCs that you know use the cloud. Typically, even if they are just hiring for non-cloud positions - e.g. linux engineer, etc. - you will more than likely have a chance to work with the cloud. That'll be a big boost to your CV as well.

Tier 2: 
Get your dream cloud job with your experience.

tldr; Cert up (to pass HR checks), know basic networking, having a homelab is really good, know 1 scripting language (e.g. python) , land any IT job first.
Recommended subreddit would be /r/sysadmin

last tip, dont be overwhelmed by /r/sysadmin. And there are different kinds of cloud jobs. Some sell the cloud (not much actual technical exp required, just understand and sell the package) usually called consultants, you got the architects who design the whole thing, you could cloud engineers, cloud administrators; each title are different job aspects and require different skills. So what i think you can do is rather than using a general statement of "i want to work with clouds", go to linkedin and find out what kind of jobs are there in the cloud industry and match what role you want to do, then develop the skills needed for that role.

replies.author: Ayman Almateeg
replies.text: @I CHENG LIN firstly I admire your braveness, not everyone is brave enough to consider such a drastic career shift so props to you for this. You can do it easily if you stay motivated and while I am no cloud expert I can say you have made a good choice by considering cloud as a future career, it is obviously picking up more more everyday. I think the AWS Cloud Practitioner Certificate is a good starting point. AWS has a fee essentials training on their webpage that could get you started and you could open a free account and play with their free services to get a feel of what is like. Some learning on basic IT principles could help before (or even after) doing this course, maybe learnt about compute, storage and network resources. You will find that these things will sound more interesting to you and you will want to keep learning. luckily, it is one of the career paths that have abundant support online in terms of learning and certification material, and the AWS platform and certification pathways are very organised. Enjoy learning and good luck!

topLevelComment.author: Cneq
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed it first try, here's what I did.

Watched all of the "Amazon AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner | ALL-IN-ONE AWS Certification Training" on UDEMY
Bought the extra practise exams on udemy [was like 400 questions] and did those until I was getting 90% to 98%
Watched this video [this video basically just covered the same stuff but it was good to hear it from another instructor as well]

And then I passed with 855/1000 and I do admit some of the questions were in fact not included on this video nor the udemy one, no idea if I got an updated test or something but at least 8 of the questions I had to basically guess [and I'd say a good 40% of the stuff included in this video and the udemy one never came up in my exam, including stuff like cloudhsm, kms, cloudformation, iam tags/resource groups, ecs, eks, opsworks, none of the business services and more] perhaps I just got a bad exam.

So yeah this video and some practise exams should at least get you over the 70% mark and hopefully you will get a test will more familiar questions. Just keep at it and you'll have no issues passing.

PS. my background is zero past AWS experiences [all I have is what I've studied above and the hands on labs they came with the udemy course] and I also only have 3 months of core IT experience [prior to that I didn't know anything, I even though the "print" in programming was referring to actually printing something lmao]. I do however recommend to have all of your bases covered in terms of foundational I.T experience before AWS, despite 3 months being pretty short it was spent on full-time self guided study and I also completed the Google IT Support Professional certificate and gained experience in a lot of other areas like linux/some security stuff [namely kali], did some SQL using mySQL, python/c++/java and some web stuff with HTML/CSS and a lot more, so just make sure you have a good high level understanding of all the different areas of I.T to really make sure you pass the AWS cert.

topLevelComment.author: Gabriel Vasile
topLevelComment.text: Hey, I just wanted to say thanks and to correct that an Availability Zone is NOT a data center, it's a "zone" and can have one or multiple data centers. An availability zone consists of "one or more discrete data centers, each with redundant power, networking, and connectivity, housed in separate facilities. In each zone, participating data centers are connected to each other over redundant low-latency private network links." Thanks for the tutorial, great resource!

topLevelComment.author: Roy Donk
topLevelComment.text: While this is a great introduction and overview of AWS and its services, if you're brand new to AWS and are planning on taking the test, this video alone is absolutely not enough to pass the test. After watching the video, read the white-papers and take multiple practice exams. There are many, many questions that aren't directly addressed in this video alone. The test questions get really specific about services that are only mentioned in passing in this video. And some of the questions blatantly try to trick you. Don't listen to the people here that say "I watched this video in two days and I passed it on my first try!" They are either liars or they have extensive prior experience with AWS or other cloud services.

topLevelComment.author: testerz3
topLevelComment.text:
Great material shown in a concise, albeit slightly fast, presentation. Thoroughly enjoyed the materials covered. I intend to take the CCP exam next week and will be incorporating some of the other users' comments on what sub-sections of this 4 hour presentation to review over a few times and commit to memory. If I may make 2 quick recommendations for future videos to further strengthen the presentations: 

1. I know there is a lot of content to cover in a condensed video. But if you can not end each sentence/phrase with a higher intonation, if would offer the listener a slight, mental breather and signal a brief pause to the material presented. Currently, most sentences "bounce up" in octave at the end; ends up sounding as if everything was just 1 really long string of thoughts w/o pause or punctuation. Insert a comma and period in your voice every now and then.

2. Try not to end up sound like Mr. Mackey from South Park. Be mindful of the "okays" at the end of each sentence.

Great job otherwise!

topLevelComment.author: imrolok
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed the AWS Cloud Practitioner exam on the first try. I had zero experience with AWS, or any other cloud tech.  (what else are you going to do when sheltering in place?)  
Here's what I did in order:
1) watched this video twice. 
2) took some udemy sample exams (3 for $20) twice. 
3) watched the free aws training videos once. 
Nice that with Pearson VUE you can take the test remotely.

Andrew Brown, the images in your video are super helpful -- in particular the ones that show the Free, Developer, Business, Enterprise benefits, and the diagram with instances, NACL, and IGW (although you have two versions of it -- one right facing and one left facing.  Would be better to use the same layout and also have the split text above correspond to the left/right of the image below).



The udemy exams had some content I hadn't seen, so those were helpful for that.



The aws training video had one segment where they showed user/group/role/policy that clarified some things for me.

topLevelComment.author: Alros Avellana
topLevelComment.text:
I passed my exam over the weekend using this and the architecture best practice white paper which I think helped a lot in some of the finer details!

The one option is correct questions were fair but I had trouble with the multiple choice ones because I feel like I’d mix details.

For example, one I remember is a question about amazon organizations and how this company wants to combine all their bills into one, the 2 answers that were similar was 1) create a new a account for organizations and have all the accounts they want join it. 2) configure an account for organizations and have all the other accounts linked to it

I didn’t actually know cause I didn’t go that in-depth into it as far as the course goes but just an example for ya.

Also a bunch in architecting. 
Which is the most EFFICIENT, or most COST EFFECTIVE , all of the answers could solve the solution but only one of them is the most cost effective.

Anyway thanks to this course and the different resources you guys have! Wouldn’t have passed without this!

replies.author: imrolok

topLevelComment.author: Mариbella Vorotnik
topLevelComment.text:
Passed AWS CCP from the first attempt. This video helped me a lot, thank you to Andrew Brown, okay!
My background: almost 1 year in high-level experience with some AWS services: EC2, IAM, DynamoDB, Lambda, API Gateway.
My CCP preparation roadmap: 
1. AWS Cloud Practitioner Essentials (Second Edition) course (it's free). You have to completely understand the information from it.
2. This video. I was noting the main information during listening.
3. Certified Cloud Practitioner course on Exampro ($20)
4. Overview of Amazon Web Services whitepaper (read it basically)

In my opinion it would be enough to pass the exam. Good luck!

topLevelComment.author: Tom Steiner
topLevelComment.text:
Just passed the AWS Cloud Practitioner exam on the first try.  My steps: (1) Watched the whole 4 hour video in 4 different sittings @ ~1 hour each (2) Did a practice exam ($20) (3) Skipped through this YouTube video again to basically read through concept/high-level definitions.  (4) Took the Pearson VUE online test and passed in about 43 minutes.  I greatly appreciate this video.  Thank you!

Note: Since many of you ask about prior experience, I did work with AWS in 2011-2013 in selling it to the public sector.  I literally held meetings with clients, presented our Professional Services capabilities, wrote proposals, and closed the deal.  So did have some background knowledge which I was able to build upon from 7 years ago.

topLevelComment.author: Steve Dougherty
topLevelComment.text: @ExamPro at about the 35-minute mark you talk about the cost of the budgets and mention it is 2 cents for every budget beyond the first 2 and that is $14 per month. Did I miss something else in that cost because I was thinking more like 60 cents per month

replies.author: Tianna Woodson
replies.text: @ExamPro I think your math is wrong here. You're multiplying 0.02 by the hours in a month, not the days in a month and Budgets cost 2 cents per DAY. The math should be 0.02*31=0.62. 62 cents per month.

replies.author: ExamPro
replies.text: Each subsequent budget will incur a $0.02 daily cost.  So if you ran one budge for a month (730 hours) 0.02*730=$14.6

replies.author: mykalimba
replies.text: You do not need to pay before using AWS on a new account, with some caveats. 1) You need a credit card on file, 2) Only some of the services have a "free tier eligible" option, and using anything that is not free tier eligible, or using more than the allocated free tier amount of a free tier service will cost you $.
